rows.title: Your CYOA Template
rows.titleText:
This serves as a template for creating an interactive CYOA. Hopefully useful to new builders.

This is the top of the CYOA, generally where a banner/logo could be placed or a brief introduction to your CYOA.

Bellow will be a series of Tabs/Buttons where you can click one to open/close sections of your CYOA.

rows.title: You
rows.titleText:
There are a few styles authors use to offer this section. From different rows for height, age, race, gender, sex, hair color, eye color... There are many ways to handle this. Personally I prefer to keep things simple.

I also would not include Row Text for this row.

rows.title: You1
rows.titleText:
The way I handle this is a tad complicated. With many factors taken into account such changing individual choices to have set "Object Width" and using the "Functions: Makes another choice unselected" to stop certain choices from being selected together.

I'd also not include Row Title or Row Text for this row.

rows.title: You2
rows.titleText: This side I tend to use to allow descriptions of some of the choices on the left side. For me this is to make things more compact and clean. To make this work properly you have to Open Row Settings with the top right icon of the Row editor and then go to Use Private Styling. From there open the Manage Filter Design and toggle "Hide The Choice Completely". Be sure to do this only after you have made all the UI changes you want with the cyoa styles. WIth that done I set these choices to have requirements that link to the relevant choice in "You1" row. I'd also not include Row Title or Row Text for this row.

objects.title: Insert
objects.text: You will awaken in your new body at your selected age with memories and history that correspond with your choices.

objects.title: Drop-In
objects.text: You will be dropped into the world in a new body with no history or memories of living in this world prior.

objects.title: Young
objects.text: You start off as a young kid no older than 8.

objects.title: Teen
objects.text: You start off as a teenager between the ages 13 and 17.

objects.title: Adult
objects.text: You start off as an adult over 21 years old.

objects.title: Era:
objects.text: This is a description of the era you've chosen to start in.

objects.title: Era: 2
objects.text: This is a description of the era you've chosen to start in.

objects.title: Era: 3
objects.text: This is a description of the era you've chosen to start in.

rows.title: You Alternative
rows.titleText:
This is a somewhat more standard way some authors show their "you" section using a series of rows and choices. This is easier and less complicated than my method and might be more aesthetically pleasing depending on your preferences.

This method makes it much easier and cleaner if you plan to have a lot of options such as race, sexuality, hair color, height and other various choices.

rows.title: Location
rows.titleText: This is generally the section where the player chooses what location they will start. This is usually a "one choice" row, as such the "Allowed Choices" is set to 1.

objects.title: Location 3
objects.text: This is an example of a location choice that costs you 5 points.

objects.title: Location 4
objects.text: This is an example of a location choice that rewards you 5 points.

rows.title: Drawbacks
rows.titleText: This is the sectional usually used to offer choices for Drawbacks to gain extra points. Normally this section comes near the end, but I prefer to have it first because it's easier to plan out the rest of the build if I get the chosen drawbacks selected first so I know how many points I have to work with.

objects.title: Choice
objects.text:
This is an example of a drawback that rewards 5 points.

When adjusting the "value" of a score, going into negatives such as -5 translates into the choice giving points rather than taking them away.

objects.title: Choice
objects.text: This is an example of a drawback that rewards 10 points.

rows.title: Gear
rows.titleText:
This is the section typically used to offer items or gear.

This example is "plain" and offers no "freebies".

objects.title: Gear 1
objects.text: This is an example of a gear o r item that costs 5 points.

objects.title: Gear 6
objects.text: This is an example of a gear or item that costs 10 points.

rows.title: Gear [with Freebies]
rows.titleText: This is the section typically used to offer items or gear. This example is a gear section that allows the player to choose a set number of items or gear for free. In this example, only gear priced at 5 points is offered free. If you have gear choices with varying prices it can be tricky to offer freebies otherwise. In this example 3 freebies are allowed. You can increase this number in [Open Features] - [Manage Points] - [Gear: Starting Sum]. You can also make the free gear points be visible in the point bar if you remove the "hidden" part in the "Id Needed to Show" box of the point management. Or, alternatively, you can make it only show up when you have opened the Gear tab, same as this section, by changing "hidden" to "tab-gear".

objects.title: Gear 1
objects.text:
How am I doing this? In the Scores I have set two Scores. One for 5 points, and one for 1 Gear point. 

These two scores have requirements attached for "Equal to" and "More Than", but linked to your current "Gear" point.

What this means is that if you have any "Gear" points, or "More than 0", selecting this use 1 Gear point.

Furthermore if your Gear points "equal to 0" it will instead cost you 5 points.

This has the effect of allowing you to choose however many "Gear points" you have set as freebies.

objects.title: Gear 6
objects.text: This is an example of a gear or item that costs 10 points.

rows.title: Talents
rows.titleText: This is usually the row used to allow talents or skills to be chosen.

rows.title: Talents [with Freebies]
rows.titleText: This is usually the row used to allow talents or skills to be chosen. This example is a talent section that allows the player to choose a set number of talents for free. In this example 2 freebies are allowed. You can increase this number in [Open Features] - [Manage Points] - [Talents: Starting Sum]. You can also make the free talent points be visible in the point bar if you remove the "hidden" part in the "Id Needed to Show" box of the point management. Or, alternatively, you can make it only show up when you have opened the Powers tab, same as this section, by changing "hidden" to "tab-talents".

objects.title: Talent 1
objects.text:
How am I doing this? In the Scores I have set two Scores. One for 5 points, and one for 1 Talent point. 

These two scores have requirements attached for "Equal to" and "More Than", but linked to your current "Talent" point.

What this means is that if you have any "Talent" points, or "More than 0", selecting this use 1 Talent point.

Furthermore if your Talent points "equal to 0" it will instead cost you 5 points.

This has the effect of allowing you to choose however many "Talent points" you have set as freebies.

rows.title: Powers
rows.titleText:
Often times this is the row used to offer powers.

If you want, you can limit the number of power choices a player can make by changing the "Allowed Choices" number of this Row.

objects.title: Power-1
objects.text: This is an example of a power priced at 5 points.

objects.title: Power-5
objects.text: This is an example of a power priced at 10 points.

rows.title: Powers [with Freebies]
rows.titleText: Often times this is the row used to offer powers. If you want, you can limit the number of power choices a player can make by changing the "Allowed Choices" number of this Row. This example is a power section that allows the player to choose a set number powers for free. In this example, only powers priced at 5 points are offered free. If you have power choices with varying prices it can be tricky to offer freebies otherwise. In this example 1 freebie is allowed. You can increase this number in [Open Features] - [Manage Points] - [Power: Starting Sum]. You can also make the free power points be visible in the point bar if you remove the "hidden" part in the "Id Needed to Show" box of the point management. Or, alternatively, you can make it only show up when you have opened the Powers tab, same as this section, by changing "hidden" to "tab-powers".

objects.title: Power-1
objects.text:
This is an example of a power priced at 5 points.

How am I doing this? In the Scores I have set two Scores. One for 5 points, and one for 1 Power point. 

These two scores have requirements attached for "Equal to" and "More Than", but linked to your current "Power" point.

What this means is that if you have any "Power" points, or "More than 0", selecting this use 1 Power point.

Furthermore if your Power points "equal to 0" it will instead cost you 5 points.

This has the effect of allowing you to choose however many "Power points" you have set as freebies.

objects.title: Power-5
objects.text: This is an example of a power priced at 10 points.

rows.title: Boons
rows.titleText: This is generally the row where the player can choose boons.

rows.title: Boons [with Freebies]
rows.titleText: This is generally the row where the player can choose boons. This example is a talent section that allows the player to choose a set number of boons for free. In this example 2 freebies are allowed. You can increase this number in [Open Features] - [Manage Points] - [Boon: Starting Sum].

objects.title: Boon 1
objects.text:
How am I doing this? In the Scores I have set two Scores. One for 5 points, and one for 1 Boon point. 

These two scores have requirements attached for "Equal to" and "More Than", but linked to your current "Boon" point.

What this means is that if you have any "Boon" points, or "More than 0", selecting this use 1 Boon point.

Furthermore if your Boon points "equal to 0" it will instead cost you 5 points.

This has the effect of allowing you to choose however many "Boon points" you have set as freebies.

rows.title: Credits
rows.titleText:
This row is typically used to show credits and changelog. For better aesthics I'd leave the Row Title and Row Text blank.

Seeing the row to "Non-activatable" is also important if you don't want the player to be able to "select" these choices.

objects.title: Credits
objects.text:
This is generally where I feature credits such as author link and relevant information.

This template was designed by LordValmar

objects.title: Changelog
objects.text: This is generally where I place the changelog to keep track of what version the CYOA is on and notes of what changes have been made.
